statement.p: Kelly is conducting market research on the cost of homeowners insurance. Kelly has determined that the average annual cost of homeowners insurance is 835, and that the distribution of costs is normally distributed with a standard deviation of 95.
a. Find the probability that a single randomly selected consumer spends more than 779 on homeowners insurance.
b. The cost of the middle 50 of homeowners insurance policies falls between (round to the nearest dollar):
c. The most expensive 20 of homeowners insurance policies cost at least how much annually?

solution.p: Define the normal distribution in Desmos: \displaystyle{N}=\text{normaldist}{\left({835},{95}\right)}.

b. For the middle 50 of the data, need the remaining 50 of the data split between the left and right tails of the distribution. So the lower bound of the range has \displaystyle{0.25} of the area to the left and the upper bound of the range has \displaystyle{0.25} of the area to the right, which means \displaystyle{0.75} to the left.
